title: Angels & Demons (film) font
content:
Hello everybody,  
I was wondering if someone over here could tell me what is the name of the font used in the “Angels & Demons” logotype of the film version, and where I can get it.

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [Angels & Demons.png](http://web.archive.org/web/20091128110014/http:/typophile.com/files/Angels%20&%20Demons.png) | 55.84 KB |
author: alkarnur

comments.content: I don’t know what typeface they used, but it’s a pity that they didn’t use the [ambigram that was on the book](http://web.archive.org/web/20091128110014/http:/www.johnlangdon.net/angelsanddemons.php) (the top one).

It looks like a mix of at least 3 fonts; there’s are Caslon and Garamond elements, and I don’t know where they got the splayed M. I modified your image and broke it into 2; try using these in MyFont’s identifont feature.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20091128110014im_/http:/typophile.com/files/AngelsRespaced_4270.png)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20091128110014im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Demons_Respaced_6097.png)
How silly of me, and I just used Cochin yesterday!
Thanks a lot you guys! I checked it and it really is good old Cochin :)

Mark, have you done movie fonts on your blog? It sure is one of your specialties.

- Mike Yanega

Sort of. I critique the way fonts are used _in_ movies from time to time—mainly about whether the fonts are correct for the period depicted in a movie. However, Yves Peters has been regularly writing about the way fonts are used on movie posters and other publicity on FontShop’s Unzipped blog ( [http://www.fontshop.be/index.php?l=11](http://web.archive.org/web/20091128110014/http:/www.fontshop.be/index.php?l=11 "http://www.fontshop.be/index.php?l=11") ).
